name: Initiative Variants
description: Two variant initiative systems that change how turn order is determined. Speed Factor modifies individual initiative rolls based on actions chosen. Side Initiative simplifies combat by having each side roll once.

variants.name: Speed Factor Initiative
variants.description: At the start of each round, each creature declares what it intends to do, then rolls initiative with modifiers based on the chosen action. Initiative is re-rolled each round.
variants.changingActions: If a creature changes its declared action on its turn, it can do so but acts last in the current initiative order for that round.

variants.name: Side Initiative
variants.description: Instead of each creature rolling individually, one representative from each side rolls 1d20 (no modifiers). The side with the highest roll acts first. All members of a side act in any order they choose on their side's turn.
procedure: Each side designates one creature to roll 1d20 (no ability modifiers)
The side with the highest roll takes their turns first
All creatures on the winning side take their turns in any order
Then all creatures on the losing side take their turns in any order
Re-roll each round or keep the same order for the entire combat (DM's choice)

interactions: Speed Factor makes higher-level spells and heavy weapons less agile, rewarding light weapon users and cantrip-focused casters
Speed Factor re-rolls initiative each round, significantly increasing combat bookkeeping
Side Initiative is much simpler and faster but removes individual initiative bonuses (Alert feat, high Dexterity) from being meaningful
Side Initiative allows tactical coordination since all members of a side can choose their action order
The Alert feat and features that add to initiative (such as the War Magic Wizard) have reduced value under Side Initiative
Side Initiative can create 'rocket tag' situations where the winning side alpha-strikes before the losing side can react
